comments.commentBody: By now it should be obvious to all but the comatosed. The republicans belief in small government is a total farce. They only believe in small government when it means less money going to the poor and needy. They are the first ones to yell incompetence or worse when the results of their "free enterprise, no government regulations" run amok ie BP oil well disaster, wild fires out of control etc. They are also the first one to yell "hands of my Medicare " and accuse the government of creating death panels when it comes to their medicare.

Inequality can be spectacularly reduced by introducing SECOND INCOMES. See that heading under MORE at www.aesopinstitute.org

Louis Kelso, father of the Employee Stock Ownership Plan - ESOP - utilized at 11,000 companies, created the idea that we all need second incomes.

His work has been continued by a growing group of dedicated individuals at the Center for Economic and Social Justice,

Second Incomes would be independent of jobs and savings.

By about age 50, almost every American would be able to have enough income from diversified investments to dramatically reduce the work week.

Herbert Marcuse, in his brilliant book Eros and Civilization, defined toil as work we do not choose. Work we choose he viewed as fitting within the definition of play.

He felt if we could lower the toil week below 25 hours civilization would experience a remarkable, extremely positive, transformation.

Technology has made that possible.

Climate Change makes it incredibly urgent to end the use of fossil fuels faster than most might believe possible. Revolutionary green energy is being born and can sharply boost the economy and generate jobs during the transition. See the AESOP Institute website.

If we are wise enough to create what Kelso called The Second Income Plan, poverty and inequality would decline in a manner consistent with our ideals.

We can create a model for other nations that might become the first genuinely free society in human history.

That's fantastic that you are concerned for the plight of these animals. I hope you share the same compassion for the billions of other breeds of animals which are treated as badly, or worse, every day in your country, my country, everywhere in the world.

You state: "God's creation needs our protection and, it is our duty to not let it be destroyed for money." This is what the meat, poultry and dairy industries do. All species should be afforded the same basic life rights. All.
I would not elevate weakness and indecision to the status of a "strategy."

This comment is directed at the "Obama Returns to Action" "News Analysis" and some of the conjecture in this article.  Why must the press seek to personalize the actions of the President in terms of what he "wants" vs. what he does or doesn't "do" as though he is incapable of both principled and pragmatic decision-making.  From what I've seen, Mr. Obama has pursued a coherent strategy, even if it is not to the liking of everyone, or as bluntly ideological as his predecessor.

Iraq.

Bush rushed in to get re-elected. Obama rushed out to get re-elected. Neither deserved the reward the voters gave them.

Forget about fairness or morality. Let's just look at economics to see why inequality is bad.

Experiments are hard to come by in economics, but we have a couple in the US to look at since WWI. There have been two medium long periods of very high inequality (Gini about 0.5), the 1920's and the 2000's. Both led to periods of disastrous economics, On the other hand, there was the long period of 1946 - 1973 (Gini about 0.25) which was a period of great prosperity. Since I do not place much faith in any economic theory, this evidence makes me believe that high inequality is very bad for the country.

But I know people like explanations. The want to know why. So I'll give it a shot.

1. Inequality depresses demand. A non-rich person must spend a greater percentage of his income to live than a Rich one. When many people are out of work, or are underpaid, when inequality is high, the non-rich do not have enough money to buy the stuff they need or want. They may want a new car, but they cannot afford it. This means businesses are not expanding because they do not have enough customers. You cannot create demand out of thin air. It requires getting money to people to spend it.

2. Inequality encourages financial speculation. What do the Rich do when they have so much money they cannot remember how many houses they own? They speculate with it. There is a definite correlation.. http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1661746

What does wild speculation do? See 1929 & 2008

http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/the-u-s-neglects-its-best-scie...

'...the programs that get funded in K–12 education do not support students who are already good at and in love with science. These students have potential for outstanding contributions, but without public investment they will not be prepared for the rigors of a scientific career. This is especially true for those without highly educated and resource-rich parents.

This lack of investment is not a matter of chance. It is the result of two related myths about who these students are and what they need from our education system. The first myth is that all talented students come from privileged backgrounds. A second is that students who are successful at a particular time in their school career can somehow thrive on their own, unassisted and unsupervised. We argue that all children deserve to be challenged cognitively, including the most able. Many students with low socioeconomic backgrounds never get the opportunity to develop their talents beyond the rudimentary school curriculum. Jonathan Plucker of the University of Connecticut has shown that high-achieving, low-income students fall further behind their higher-socioeconomic-status peers the closer they get to graduation. Moreover, international comparison studies show science scores improving for all students except those in the top 10 percent.'

This is a very complex situation and it is of our own creation due to poor planning under GWB and the poor foresight of supporting rebels in Syria. A power vacuum was created in the region and we're responsible for weakening every authority that ruled.

Dropping aid on refuges and bombs on ISIS is the least we should do and is far better than reengaging ourselves in Iraq.

I wish we had stayed out of Syria, perhaps ISIS would not have grown from that. Honestly, if we would just ally with Russia we could probably stop many of these conflicts.

All of these proxy wars we've fought since the end of WWII have taken a toll on the region and the two countries have armed the world many times over - it's at the point where we've each armed our own enemies.

At this point we're fighting against ourselves more than against one another and it's ridiculous.

So yes, drop bombs on ISIS but the real solution will come if we finally just shake hands with Russia.

That would be fine if we lived in pre WWI - we do not.  To let terrorist forces take control of a whole region - one with the mission statement to commit genocide on Israel and then turn its attention to the USA - would be disastrous.

in response to Martin Nee...
No- these folks need to do more than stop and think before they spout off about the government. they need to accept some personal responsibility for their choices and suffer the free market consequences of their own actions.

Thank you. Most cogent and accurate article on the thread.
We let too many people make stupid decisions about living in forests, on rivers, on the ocean, and then demand that we bail them out.
With the arriving climate change, all we can probably do is mitigation.
And stop subsidizing fools.

Martin,  you  are  so   right  about   people  who   live   on  the  fringe  of   forests.  Perhaps   when  the  smoke   finally  clears,  they  might  notice   that  no   towns  of  any  size   have  burned   down  lately.  It's  time  they  live   elsewhere   and   go   visit  the  forests  for  their   beauty---then  turn  around   and   leave.

Having grown up on a midwest farm in the 1950's hearing the constant refrain of "get the government off our backs" from conservative farmers who were taking advantage of every government subsidy they could get their hands on it's an old story.  The westerners building houses in the middle of a flammable forest and expecting the government to save their house (which never should have been built there in the first place) and then expecting government help to rebuild-often in the same spot.  Similiar situation with houses on the coasts, rivers and lakes all over the country- built where flooding is even more likely to occur because of global warming- expecting government help to rebuild after flooding Guess where?  Same spot.  If these farmers and homeowners want the government help I think the least they should do is maybe, just maybe stop and think before they start chanting "get the government off our backs".
20,000 stranded on a mountain?  And you babble about a "recession"?

Actually, while there are similarities between the two groups, intelligence agencies believe these are merely marginalized Sunnis, pushed to the brink by Shiites Baghdad, that are rallying around the ISIS flag. So in essence, it does go back to the original sin of the invasion itself.
It is so sad that many Americans aren't seeing this. They are one of the rare civilized and organized people's in the region. I hope the American people come around to this fact.
The Kurds are worthy of being defended.

We have this murderous sectarian fighting because Mr. Obama has allowed Iraq, Egypt, Libya and Syria to slide back into the flames.
He has done NOTHING.
And now he's doing too little, too late.
You want a "good debate at the U.N."?
What good has that ever done?

Can one imagine that Iraq would be worse off to-day if it had stayed with Saddam Hussein instead of our invasion and the Brenner vice-royalty? Bad as Saddam's dictatorship was it didn't have this current dreadful sectarian murderous fighting, not to mention what our invasion caused in lives. Now there is a truly humanitarian catastrophe and we can be really thankful that we have a thoughtful person in Barak at the helm to concentrate on the humanitarian problem.
What has bothered me is the absence of majors like Russia, China and Europe in the face of ISIS/ISIL. After all, they have all been with us on the Iran situation which didn't seem to present the humanitarian problem we now see in Iraq/Kurdistan. What do they see in Iraq that give them less concern than we feel? Let's hope that we get a good debate in the UN.
I don't think these token gestures are going to prevent anything.
I am so glad our President decided to intervene to protect our Consulate in Irbil and to prevent the genocide of 40,000 Assyrian Christians who have fled ISIS.
They would still hate us. Don't kid yourself.

End corruption in Congress. http://youtu.be/i3X2eDCmPRY

Vote Republicans out of government, state and federal.

Bruce, I hesitate to reply because you are the author.  But. every novel and every puzzle is subject to various interpretations.  That is why humans are different from plants.  I see the fish but I coulda been a contender.  Far be it from me to give advice to someone who has constructed a NYT puzzle but you should relish that people look at your puzzle through so many PRISMs.
Oh for pete's sake, get a sense of humor. That's entirely the point of the title. I think it's funny and rather charming.

No doubt the headline writer is aware that to "pre-game" in college circles means to drink hard liquor in enough quantities to get drunk before going out to public parties where drinking may be restricted by campus authorities.  It is a dangerous (and sad) practice.  In this context, the term is misplaced.  "Grown-ups," presumably don't need to "pre-game."
Time to provide arms to the Kurds.  In fact, long, long overdue.  If the Kurds are overtaken, there will be genocide.

I hate to break the news to you, but as a former college prep high school teacher for many years, the Ivy League does in fact recruit athletes and the Ivy League does factor in athletic ability as one of the components determining financial aid awards.

Consider the example of a young man who has compiled a 3.8 or 3.9 high school GPA in a curriculum sprinkled with honors and A.P. courses, and who then scores a 30 on the ACT. That student will stand in roughly the 40th percentile of applicants to schools like Brown or Dartmouth, and probably the 20th percentile of applicants to a school like Harvard.

But--if that student is also a strong mid-major football prospect who would be likely to succeed as an athlete at Marshall or Miami of Ohio, then his stock as an applicant to an Ivy League school is dramatically enhanced. That's because he's a rare combination of factors--a very strong student--meaning middling strong by Ivy League standards--as well as a very strong athlete--though not up to Big 5 Conference standards. And Ivy League coaches do track down such prospects through networks of alumni or college counselors or word of mouth, and such students often end up playing sports at the Ivies on a combination of need and merit based financial aid.

But, if not for their athletic ability, they would not have been admitted in the first place. Because just like an exceptional harpsichordist or dancer, they possess a skill which helps them stand out in a very talented crowd.

“The author's insistence that all Jew's offer blind support for the actions of the Israeli government has disturbing echos from the recent past, a period Jews are told must never happen again.”

@ Kevin Rothstein

"Sometimes it feels as if liberal Zionist critics are trying to ensure that Israel’s deeds do not rub off on them."

As well they should.

Netanyahu has led Israel into doing some horrible things.

There is no moral imperative to tie all Jews everywhere to those horrible things. It is the state of Israel under its current right wing crazies, not all Jews everywhere.

There is no moral imperative on any American Jew to own those horrible things Netanyahu has done. Most American Jews voted for Obama, and would never vote for Netanyahu, which is the clear either/or choice Netanyahu has defined since before the 2012 election.

Shame on Bill Gates and Warren Buffet for depriving people of opportunities, and then depriving the federal gov't of much needed tax revenue by donating to their charity and bypassing any current tax dollars owed, plus taxes owed upon their death.

But the key to Vast Fortunes for the Malefactors of Great Wealth is to continue to fund the self referencing "think" tanks and funding their propaganda channel to discredit evidence based studies you are citing as "Liberal Talking Points"

I heard (Twice) last week while ringing doorbells for a legislative candidate that it has been "Proven that tax cuts pay for themselves." So don't confuse them with evidence from Kansas or Detroit.

Why worry about growing the pie, when you can steal a dollar from every poor person in America. That's a lot of dollars, and seems to be the way many of the current wealth creation schemes work.

Our current economic scheme is based on depriving others of opportunities.

Never mind Britain and Turkey - where are the Chinese? It is my understanding that they own most of the oil production there now... History will show that this was our war so China could have cheap access to oil. Shouldn't they be in there to protect it? China: Time to put on your big boy pants and play in the big leagues!

Did Obama refuse to bargain about a residual force? I recall that Maliki would have none of it, and that Iraqis refused to renegotiate the deal leaving no residual force that Bush signed. Please straighten me out?
